author: Duncan Lindsay
title: EastEnders boss Sean O’Connor disccuses community storylines and Ronnie and Roxy Mitchell’s deaths
text:
(Picture: BBC) EastEnders’ boss Sean O’Connor has spoken out about taking leadership of the popular show, explaining his interest in exploring the concept of community in a world that is currently divided in so many ways. 
Of late, viewers have noticed a stark difference in EastEnders episodes, with many praising the soap’s back-to-roots direction and focus on more realistic stories from school bullying and depression through to debt and even bin collections.
Speaking to the Royal Television Society , who hold their awards tonight in which EastEnders are nominated for the Soaps and Continuing Drama prize, Sean explained: ‘I’m interested in the idea of community in a world that is quite fractured at the moment, whether that be by Brexit or Trump. I think the idea of community is being questioned, maybe even threatened, and all soaps are about community.

‘EastEnders is not realistic, it’s always been a fantasy, a fiction of what community is but in that fantasy or fiction there is a deeper truth, and it’s to do with the robustness of the format.’
He also touched upon the much talked about deaths of Ronnie and Roxy Mitchell earlier this year, in an episode that saw the doomed sisters drown together after Ronnie married Jack Branning.
He said: ‘They were not the sort of characters that would leave in the back of a taxi – we wanted to give them an operatic ending.’
(Picture: BBC) Another huge talking point recently has been the re-cast of Michelle Fowler. Sean is pleased with how the return of the massive character is going, adding that new star Jenna Russell has the ‘full seal of approval’ from her predecessor Susan Tully.
He shared: ‘She is one of the iconic, original characters of the show. We had the choice that we never investigate that rich, fertile character again or we get someone else to do it and that’s exactly what we’ve done.’
